question_text: Why does particle-driven CSP enable higher thermodynamic cycle efficiencies compared to molten salt systems, and what specific physical limitations of molten salts does this overcome?
standard_answer: Particle-driven CSP enables higher thermodynamic cycle efficiencies primarily by overcoming the thermal stability and temperature limitations of molten salts. Molten salt systems are constrained by salt decomposition above 600°C and solidification below 220°C, limiting operating temperatures to 565°C bulk temperature. This restricts power cycles to subcritical Rankine cycles with ~42% efficiency. Particle suspensions can operate above 800°C without temperature limitations except receiver wall constraints, enabling advanced thermodynamic cycles. The higher temperature operation increases Carnot efficiency proportionally to (1-T_cold/T_hot). Specifically, particles enable supercritical steam cycles at 650-670°C (48% efficiency), supercritical CO2 cycles at 700-750°C, and externally heated gas turbines at 850°C. The physical mechanisms include: particles have no phase change limitations, avoiding freezing risks; they maintain structural stability at high temperatures; and they enable larger temperature differences in storage (ΔT ~270°C vs 90°C for parabolic troughs). This larger ΔT increases storage density and reduces thermal mass requirements. Additionally, particles avoid corrosion issues associated with high-temperature molten salts and enable refractory-lined receivers that can withstand temperatures exceeding 1000°C.

original_text.1: The molten salt working temperature in a central receiver CSP results in a heat-to-electricity efficiency of approximately 42%. Higher efficiencies (~48% and more) are attainable at 650–670°C with advanced supercritical steam cycles, with supercritical carbon dioxide (sCO2) cycles at 700–750°C with hot air turbines operated in externally heated combined cycle gas turbines.
original_text.2: Since the powder has a heat capacity similar to that of molten salts, without temperature limitation except for the maximum allowable wall temperature of the receiver, a suspension temperature in excess of 1000°C can be achieved
